title: Arduino Serial Communication & Motor Control - Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Serial communication and PWM motor control in Arduino.

questions.question: What does Serial.begin(9600) do?
options: Sends data to the LCD screen
questions.explanation: Serial.begin(9600) starts communication with your computer at 9600 bits per second.

questions.question: Which of the following prints a message to the Serial Monitor with a new line?
questions.explanation: Serial.println() prints text followed by a newline character.

questions.question: What is the common baud rate used for beginner Arduino projects?
questions.explanation: 9600 baud is the most common beginner-friendly speed for Arduino serial communication.

questions.question: What does PWM stand for?
questions.explanation: PWM stands for Pulse Width Modulation, used to control motor speed and LED brightness.

questions.question: What happens if both motor pins are set to 0 with analogWrite()?
questions.explanation: Giving both motor pins 0 stops the motor.

questions.question: How do you make a DC motor spin backward using two motor pins?
options: Give PWM to pin A, 0 to pin B
Give 0 to pin A, PWM to pin B
questions.explanation: Giving PWM > 0 to pin A and 0 to pin B makes the motor spin backward.

questions.question: Which function is used to send sensor values to the Serial Monitor for debugging?
questions.explanation: Serial.println() sends text or numbers to the Serial Monitor.

questions.question: What is the range of PWM values in Arduino’s analogWrite()?
questions.explanation: PWM values range from 0 (off) to 255 (full power).

questions.question: In the tryThisCode, what does Serial.println("Moving forward"); do?
options: Sends the text 'Moving forward' to the Serial Monitor
questions.explanation: Serial.println("Moving forward"); only prints a message, it doesn’t control the motor directly.

questions.question: If you want the motor to move forward at half speed, what PWM value should you use?
questions.explanation: Half speed corresponds to about 128 in the 0–255 PWM range.
